candidates.title: The Winograd Schema Challenge
candidates.reason: Directly inspired the paper’s core contribution: the Winogender schemas are designed in the Winograd style and even used for MTurk validation.

candidates.title: Stanford’s Multi-Pass Sieve Coreference Resolution System at the CoNLL-2011 Shared Task
candidates.reason: One of the three concrete systems evaluated (RULE), central to the experimental analysis of gender bias.

candidates.title: Learning Anaphoricity and Antecedent Ranking Features for Coreference Resolution
candidates.reason: Representative statistical coreference system evaluated (STAT), directly used in the main experiments.

candidates.title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Mention-Ranking Coreference Models
candidates.reason: Representative neural coreference system evaluated (NEURAL), central to the comparative bias analysis.

candidates.title: Bootstrapping Path-Based Pronoun Resolution
candidates.reason: Noun Gender and Number, Provides the B&L gender/number counts resource used by many systems and explicitly used to correlate system bias with textual gender statistics.

candidates.title: Semantics derived automatically from language corpora contain human-like biases
candidates.reason: Supplies the 60 one-word occupation list used to construct the evaluation schemas and frames the link between text and human-like biases.

candidates.title: The Social Impact of Natural Language Processing
candidates.reason: Provides terminology and framing for types of bias (e.g., overgeneralization) explicitly referenced in the paper.

candidates.title: Big Data's Disparate Impact
candidates.reason: Motivates the study of bias in data-driven systems and supports the paper’s broader argument about societal impact.

candidates.title: Gender Bias in Coreference Resolution: Evaluation and Debiasing Methods
candidates.reason: Independent but closely related concurrent work (WinoBias) proposing a similar evaluation; discussed as complementary to this paper’s focus.

candidates.title: Improving Coreference Resolution by Learning Entity-Level Distributed Representations
candidates.reason: Background on neural coreference advancements and feature learning, cited to contextualize model capabilities and potential bias sources.

candidates.title: Learning Global Features for Coreference Resolution
candidates.reason: Background on global inference improvements in coreference, supporting the system taxonomy used in the study.

candidates.title: Learning Structured Perceptrons for Coreference Resolution with Latent Antecedents and Non-local Features
candidates.reason: Background establishing statistical systems surpassing rule-based ones; helps frame the chosen STAT baseline.

candidates.title: Easy Victories and Uphill Battles in Coreference Resolution
candidates.reason: General coreference evaluation context; tangential support for discussing system behavior and challenges.

candidates.title: CoNLL-2011 Shared Task: Modeling Unrestricted Coreference in OntoNotes
candidates.reason: Cited for dissemination context of the B&L resource within coreference evaluation; peripheral to the main analysis.

candidates.title: Man is to Computer Programmer as Woman is to Homemaker? Debiasing Word Embeddings
candidates.reason: Related work on debiasing embeddings; supports discussion of how pre-trained embeddings can inject bias into coreference systems.

candidates.title: Word embeddings quantify 100 years of gender and ethnic stereotypes
candidates.reason: Contextual evidence that textual data encode gender stereotypes, supporting the paper’s broader claims.

candidates.title: Men Also Like Shopping: Reducing Gender Bias Amplification using Corpus-level Constraints
candidates.reason: Prior work on bias amplification in NLP models; cited to situate this study within bias mitigation literature.

candidates.title: Stereotyping and Bias in the Flickr30K Dataset
candidates.reason: Prior analysis of social/gender stereotyping in datasets; provides cross-domain context.

candidates.title: Social Bias in Elicited Natural Language Inferences
candidates.reason: Prior work on social bias in NLP datasets; tangential background.

candidates.title: Gender and Dialect Bias in YouTube’s Automatic Captions
candidates.reason: Example of real-world system bias; supports motivation rather than methodology.

candidates.title: These are not the Stereotypes You are Looking For: Bias and Fairness in Authorial Gender Attribution
candidates.reason: Broader guidance on gender prediction and fairness; peripheral to the paper’s core methods.

candidates.title: Mitigating Unwanted Biases with Adversarial Learning
candidates.reason: General debiasing approach cited as related work; not used in the paper’s analysis.

candidates.title: Data Decisions and Theoretical Implications when Adversarially Learning Fair Representations
candidates.reason: Further adversarial debiasing background; least direct impact on this paper’s design and findings.
